questions.question_text_1: A certain network connection with a bandwidth of 12 Mbps allows making 4000 requests to a server per second. If each request is modified to have an additional data of 6 Kb, what should be the additional bandwidth required to maintain the rate of 4000 requests per second?
question_texts: A certain network connection with a bandwidth of 12 Mbps allows making 4000 requests to a server per second. If each request is modified to have an additional data of 6 Kb, what should be the additional bandwidth required to maintain the rate of 4000 requests per second?

questions.question_text_1: A client sitting in a train is connected to a server through a network tower that has a range of 4.5 kilometers and a constant bandwidth of 5 Mbps. The train is at a negligible distance from the tower and is moving away from it at a speed of 180 kmph. How much data (in Megabytes) will be used by the client before the train completely moves out of the coverage area, assuming that the client is consuming the entire bandwidth?
question_texts: A client sitting in a train is connected to a server through a network tower that has a range of 4.5 kilometers and a constant bandwidth of 5 Mbps. The train is at a negligible distance from the tower and is moving away from it at a speed of 180 kmph. How much data (in Megabytes) will be used by the client before the train completely moves out of the coverage area, assuming that the client is consuming the entire bandwidth?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements and choose the correct options.  Statement I: An author can write multiple books, but each book is written by only one author. Statement II: A publisher can publish multiple books, but each book is published by only one publisher. Statement III: A book belongs to one genre, but a genre can have multiple books.
question_texts: Consider the following statements and choose the correct options.  Statement I: An author can write multiple books, but each book is written by only one author. Statement II: A publisher can publish multiple books, but each book is published by only one publisher. Statement III: A book belongs to one genre, but a genre can have multiple books.

options.option_text: Statement I represents a many-to-many relationship between Author andBook.
Statement I represents a one-to-many relationship between Author and Book.
Statement II represents a one-to-many relationship between Publisher andBook.
Statement III represents a many-to-one relationship between Book and Genre.

questions.question_text_1: Match the URLs in column A with their correct rendered output in Column B with the correct app.py code for the flask application given in the previous question.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations #### HTML and CSS 1. **HTML Structure and Tags**: - Basic structure of an HTML document. - Common HTML tags: `

`, `

`, `

    `, `
  • `, ``, ``. - Attributes: `src`, `alt`, `href`, `style`, `class`, `id`. 2. **CSS Styling**: - Inline styles vs. external stylesheets. - CSS selectors: class (`.class`), ID (`#id`), element (`h2`). - CSS properties: `color`, `background-color`, `width`, `text-align`, `display`, `border`. - Specificity and inheritance in CSS. - `!important` rule in CSS. 3. **Accessibility Principles**: - WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines). - Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, Robust principles. - Use of `alt` attributes for images. #### Python and Flask 1. **Python Basics**: - String manipulation and templates. - Using `string.Template` and `jinja2.Template`. - Command-line arguments with `sys.argv`. 2. **Flask Framework**: - Basic Flask application structure. - Routing and handling HTTP methods (GET, POST). - Using `request` object to access query parameters. - Rendering templates and returning HTML responses. 3. **HTTP and Web Servers**: - Basic understanding of HTTP methods and status codes. - Running a simple Python HTTP server. - Using `curl` to make HTTP requests. #### Data Structures and Algorithms 1. **Data Structures**: - Dictionaries and lists in Python. - Grouping data and iterating through structures. 2. **Algorithms**: - Basic algorithms for data manipulation and rendering. #### Networking and Bandwidth 1. **Bandwidth Calculations**: - Understanding bandwidth requirements. - Calculating data usage based on speed and time. 2. **Network Coverage**: - Calculating data usage within a network coverage area. - Understanding the relationship between speed, distance, and data usage. #### Database Relationships 1. **Relationship Types**: - One-to-many relationships. - Many-to-one relationships. - Many-to-many relationships. #### Number Systems and Conversions 1. **Number Bases**: - Understanding octal, hexadecimal, and decimal number systems. - Converting between different number bases. ### Equations #### Networking and Bandwidth 1. **Bandwidth Calculation**: \[ \text{Additional Bandwidth} = \text{Number of Requests per Second} \times \text{Additional Data per Request} \] \[ \text{Additional Bandwidth} = 4000 \, \text{requests/sec} \times 6 \, \text{Kb/request} \] \[ \text{Additional Bandwidth} = 24000 \, \text{Kbps} = 24 \, \text{Mbps} \] 2. **Data Usage Calculation**: \[ \text{Time in Coverage Area} = \frac{\text{Coverage Distance}}{\text{Speed}} \] \[ \text{Time in Coverage Area} = \frac{4.5 \, \text{km}}{180 \, \text{km/h}} = 0.025 \, \text{hours} = 90 \, \text{seconds} \] \[ \text{Data Usage} = \text{Bandwidth} \times \text{Time} \] \[ \text{Data Usage} = 5 \, \text{Mbps} \times 90 \, \text{seconds} = 450 \, \text{Mb} = 56.25 \, \text{MB} \] #### Number Systems and Conversions 1. **Octal to Decimal Conversion**: \[ 1xy25_8 = 1 \times 8^4 + x \times 8^3 + y \times 8^2 + 2 \times 8^1 + 5 \times 8^0 \] \[ 1xy25_8 = 4096 + 512x + 64y + 16 + 5 = 4117 + 512x + 64y \] 2. **Hexadecimal to Decimal Conversion**: \[ 1ED5_{16} = 1 \times 16^3 + E \times 16^2 + D \times 16^1 + 5 \times 16^0 \] \[ 1ED5_{16} = 4096 + 14 \times 256 + 13 \times 16 + 5 = 4096 + 3584 + 208 + 5 = 7893 \] 3. **Decimal Representation**: \[ x89y_{10} = x \times 1000 + 8 \times 100 + 9 \times 10 + y = 1000x + 800 + 90 + y = 1000x + 890 + y \] 4. **Equating the Conversions**: \[ 4117 + 512x + 64y = 7893 = 1000x + 890 + y \] Solving for \( x \) and \( y \): \[ 4117 + 512x + 64y = 1000x + 890 + y \] \[ 4117 - 890 + 512x - 1000x + 64y - y = 0 \] \[ 3227 - 488x + 63y = 0 \] \[ 488x - 63y = 3227 \] Testing the given options, we find that \( x = 7 \) and \( y = 3 \) satisfy the equation. ### Mermaid Knowledge Graph #### HTML and CSS ```mermaid graph TD; A[HTML] --> B[Structure and Tags] A --> C[Attributes] B --> D[Common Tags: h1, p, ul, li, a, img] C --> E[src, alt, href, style, class, id] A --> F[CSS Styling] F --> G[Selectors: class, ID, element] F --> H[Properties: color, background-color, width, text-align, display, border] F --> I[Specificity and Inheritance] F --> J[!important Rule] A --> K[Accessibility Principles] K --> L[WCAG: Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, Robust] K --> M[alt Attributes for Images] ``` #### Python and Flask ```mermaid graph TD; A[Python] --> B[String Manipulation and Templates] B --> C[string.Template] B --> D[jinja2.Template] A --> E[Command-Line Arguments] E --> F[sys.argv] A --> G[Flask Framework] G --> H[Basic Flask Application Structure] G --> I[Routing and Handling HTTP Methods] I --> J[GET, POST] G --> K[request Object] K --> L[Accessing Query Parameters] G --> M[Rendering Templates] G --> N[Returning HTML Responses] A --> O[HTTP and Web Servers] O --> P[Running Simple Python HTTP Server] O --> Q[Using curl for HTTP Requests] ``` #### Data Structures and Algorithms ```mermaid graph TD; A[Data Structures] --> B[Dictionaries and Lists in Python] A --> C[Grouping Data and Iterating Through Structures] A --> D[Algorithms] D --> E[Data Manipulation and Rendering] ``` #### Networking and Bandwidth ```mermaid graph TD; A[Networking and Bandwidth] --> B[Bandwidth Calculations] B --> C[Number of Requests per Second] B --> D[Additional Data per Request] A --> E[Network Coverage] E --> F[Speed, Distance, and Data Usage] E --> G[Calculating Data Usage within Coverage Area] ``` #### Database Relationships ```mermaid graph TD; A[Database Relationships] --> B[One-to-Many Relationships] A --> C[Many-to-One Relationships] A --> D[Many-to-Many Relationships] ``` #### Number Systems and Conversions ```mermaid graph TD; A[Number Systems and Conversions] --> B[Octal to Decimal Conversion] A --> C[Hexadecimal to Decimal Conversion] A --> D[Decimal Representation] A --> E[Equating the Conversions] ``` This summary and the knowledge graphs should help you focus on the essential topics and understand the relationships between different concepts for your exam.
